revised_title: The Mechanism of Reciprocal Innervation and Successive Induction in Muscles
tldr: The authors conducted experiments on spinal reflexes and observed that the "flexion-reflex" of a limb is diphasic, with a first phase of flexion followed by a subsequent phase of extension. This phenomenon, called "successive induction," occurs when the extensor muscles contract after the inhibitory stimulus is removed. The authors found that the contraction phase is influenced by the intensity and duration of the stimulus, and that the process is not related to the peripheral relaxation of the muscle but rather to the central inhibition and rebound. This research contributes to the understanding of the nervous system and muscle control.
